story: One of East Lothianrsquos original sports facilities lsquoHaddington Swimming Poolrsquo, as it was first known as, opened its doors in September .The much-loved site at the Aubigny Sports Centre consists of a four-lane swimming pool and East Lothianrsquos only dedicated infant pool.Currently the facility welcomes about , bathers to the pool each week for swimming lessons, AquaFit classes, club training, school and public use.Operators enjoyleisure posted on Facebook: "After  years, Aubigny Sports Centres swimming pool hall is getting a well-earned facelt."The swimming pools and health suite will close on Tuesday for nine weeks to complete a refurbishment of the pool hall."Donrsquot worry, the rest of the sports centre will remain open for all your gym, fitness and sporting activities."The refurbishment will include both essential maintenance and interior deacutecor upgrades.The refurbishment plans include the complete replacement of custom-fit ceiling window  and a new roof covering.Inside the pool hall, following a complete drain of both pools, a light and bright ceiling covering will replace the outdated wood cladding.A new energy efficient lighting scheme will be fitted which will transform the look and feel of the facility for the benefit of all users.Furthermore, existing wall tiles will be replaced with wall liner  to complete the fresh new look.The final day of the works is scheduled to be Friday, June .Swimming lessons there are scheduled to resume on Monday, July .

title: families-flock-to-county-beaches-as-easter-holiday-temperatures-soar
story: After temperatures topped  degrees Celcius in many locations ndash including Haddington ndash on Easter Sunday, today was similarly sultry.As these pictures show, North Berwicks beaches were a popular choice for locals and visitors alike, with the golden sands at Yellowcraig and Gullane also busy.Sadly, the weather picture for the rest of the week is not quite so encouraging, although there will hopefully be some sunny periods tomorrow , but without the unseasonally high temperatures.

title: man-set-upon-by-group-of-15-people-on-north-berwick-high-street
story: The serious assaulthappened around at about .pm on High Street.Police received reports of a disturbance and on attendance a -year-old man was found with what they described as "signicant" facial injuries.He was taken to the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh for treatment.Police inquiries have established thatthe victim was attacked by a group of about  people.Anyone who can help policein identying those involved is being asked to come forward.Detective Constable James Welsh from Lothians and Scottish Borders CID said: "This has been quite a large disturbance that left the victim with a number of painful injuries to his face."North Berwick High Street was likely to have still had a number of people coming and going from the area at this time of the evening and anyone who saw what happened and has yet to contact police should do so immediately."In addition, anyone who can provide any information that can help us identy those responsible is also urged to get in touch."Contact Lothians and Scottish Borders CID via  with information and quote incident number  of April . Alternatively, an anonymous report can be made to the charity Crimestoppers on   .

title: honest-lad-and-honest-lass-candidates-set-for-elections
story: Seeking election for  are: Claire Dougal,  Aidan Maguire,  Michael Morrison,  and Abbie Thomson, .Michael has served as an attendant for the past two years and Claire was also an attendant at last yearrsquos festival, supporting Honest Lad Conor Scott and Honest Lass Katie McLaren as part of the official party.Also throwing their hats into the ring this year are Aidan and Abbie, who are also delighted to be standing as candidates.The following polling stations are open for voting Friday: Brunton Hall concourse, am-pm Musselburgh Primary Care Centre, am to pm Musselburgh Museum, .am until pm Musselburgh East Community Centre, pm until pm Musselburgh Rugby Club, pm to pmWallyford Community Centre, pm to pm Whitecraig Community Centre, pm to pm.Each polling station is operated by members of festival organisers the Honest Tounrsquos Association and overseen by volunteers from the Rotary Club of Musselburgh and Old Musselburgh Club. At the end of the election, votes are counted by an independent team and supervised by a representative of each candidate.The four candidates are now working hard to canvas for the publicrsquos vote by selling membership cards costing pound throughout the community.Once purchased, these cards can then be presented at one of the listed polling stations on election day for votes to be cast.The result of the election will initially be declared within The Brunton to the candidates, their families, local councillors and the associationrsquos committee before being announced publicly from the outside balcony of the building at about pm.In traditional style, the new Honest Lad, Honest Lass and attendants will be paraded around the town in an open carriage led by the Boysrsquo Brigade Pipe Band. Everyone is welcome to go along to hear the announcement and help get the  Musselburgh Festival off to a great start.A disco will take place in Musselburgh Rugby Club which will be open from .pm, with entry pound.Alison Elgin, association president, said: ldquoWe have four excellent candidates and they are all working hard to canvas votes. We do all that we can to ensure that the election is as fair and transparent as is possible, and we are really proud that the people of Musselburgh vote for their Honest Lad and Honest Lass each year.ldquoPlans are well under way for Festival Week  with events which will hopefully appeal to everyone."This year we are working with Musselburgh Racecourse on their Community Race Day which will be held on Sunday, September . As a result of this, we can announce that, by voting in this yearrsquos election, you will be admitted free of charge to Musselburgh Racecourse on the day when you present your membership card which will be stamped at the polling station when you vote.This yearrsquos Musselburgh Festival will run from July  to .The candidates are:Claire DougalClaire, , was born and brought up in Whitecraig, attending Whitecraig Primary and Musselburgh Grammar Schools. She works at Pinkie Farm Shop as a general assistant. She has been a member of Musselburgh Crusaders Riding Club since she was  years old and won the youngest rider trophy at the age of . She has taken part in every Musselburgh rideout since she was eight years old and has participated in numerous fancy dress parades. She has also had the pleasure of attending numerous other townsrsquo rides and festivals over the last few years. Claire enjoys spending time with friends, family and her horse Ripper. She thoroughly enjoyed last year as an attendant, visiting local schools and businesses and representing Musselburgh in the Borders. She is looking forward to representing Musselburgh in  after a fantastic year last year.Aidan MaguireAidan, , was a pupil at Loretto RC Primary School in Musselburgh before attending St Davidrsquos High School in Dalkeith. During secondary school, he held part-time positions at TK Maxx and USC. On leaving school, he was appointed as an apprentice with Slight Joinery Ltd. Aidanrsquos interests include following national rugby and football teams as well as snowboarding, and he enjoys trying new sports.He has been a spectator of the festival, watching the rideouts and fancy dress parade with his family and friends. Aidan has a good understanding of the history behind the festival and feels that this is the right time to become more involvedMichael MorrisonMichael, , attended Musselburgh Burgh Primary School and Musselburgh Grammar School. Originally living in Carberry, he moved to Musselburgh five years ago when his grandfather retired from his candle-making business. He has been involved in ious community activities since his primary school days, having been a member of the Boysrsquo Brigade, a piper with the Boysrsquo Brigade band and a member of Musselburgh Rugby Club. He played for Musselburgh both at club and district level, and has been involved with assisting the training of junior rugby players. For the past two years, he has had the honour of supporting past Honest Lad Jamie Cameron and Honest Lad Conor Scott as their attendant, and it is his ambition to become Honest Lad himself and to represent Musselburgh. His time as attendant has prepared him well for this responsibility. Michael is currently employed as a security guard. He recently gained his bus driving qualications and is keen to become a coach driver. He is looking forward to participating in the forthcoming festival and knows how enjoyable it can be for everyone.Abbie ThomsonAbbie, , has lived in Musselburgh all her le and attended Campie Primary School and Musselburgh Grammar School, where she was a prefect in her fth and sixth year. Growing up, she attended Brownies at Pinkie School and Guides at Northesk. She is currently in her final year studying BScApplied Animal Science at Scotlandrsquos Rural University College and she is due to graduate in July. Abbie began riding at the age of  and was an active member of the local pony club. She spends most of her free time with her own horse, mucking out stables at a local livery yard or volunteering at the Riding for the Disabled Association. Having grown up watching the festival and taking part in the fancy dress parade when she was younger, Abbie is delighted to be a candidate for Honest Lass. She is looking forward to representing Musselburgh as part of the official party both at home and in the Borders.

title: former-cockenzie-power-station-site-about-to-be-put-on-open-market
story: East Lothian Council is preparing to put giant signs on the former Cockenzie Power Station land inviting potential customers to make a bid.The move comes just over a year after the council formally completed the purchase of the -acre coastline site.Public consultations on the future of the site, which includes a large area of communal land, known as the Greenhills, which is used by local communities and the former coal plant site and historic Waggonway land, were carried out over two years ago.The local authority produced a masterplan for the site based on the consultations, which it described as a ldquovision document for its future.However, neighbouring communities straddling the site have opposing views on its best future development.Prestonpans Community Council has lobbied for a cruise terminal at the former power station and the council has agreed to carry out an engineering study into its feasibility.In neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton, community councillors are keen to see the masterplan, which does not support a cruise port, adopted by the local authority.It sets out a range of ideas for the site, including the potential for a marina at the waterfront, business and economic sectors, and recreational land.Despite the investment into producing the masterplan and consulting the public, the only definite project confirmed for the site so far is an unmanned substation, which will bring offshore energy onto land for Inch Cape Offshore Ltd .ICOL, which are owned by Chinese State-owned company Red Rock, was granted permission for the substation after the Scottish Ministers called in its planning application shortly after East Lothian Council bought the land.The council confirmed earlier this month that is had agreed to sell part of the land to ICOL.A bid by local group the Battle of Prestonpans Heritage Trust to buy part of the land for its own heritable project has been rejected by the council.The council told the trust it had been advised against selling until ldquosuch time as the future of the whole site has been determined.Signs promoting the land for development are expected to go up on the site within the next few weeks after they were given planning approval.They will invite all enquiries about ldquoeconomic development opportunities on the site to get in touch via email.

title: opening-hours-slashed-at-three-tsbs-in-east-lothian
story: Dropping footfall has been blamed for the hours being cut at the bankrsquos branches in Haddington, North Berwick and Dunbar.The changes will come into force from the end of July and will not affect the Musselburgh TSB branch.A spokeswoman for TSB said that there had been a drop of eight per cent in customer transactions in Haddington, three per cent in Dunbar and one per cent in North Berwick.Currently, the branches in Dunbar, Haddington and North Berwick are all open from .am to .pm from Monday to Friday, with a lunch hour .-.pm.However, from the end of July, the TSB branch in Haddington will only be open Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday, while the North Berwick branch will only be open between those hours on a Tuesday and Friday, and Dunbar will be open on a Monday and Thursday.Carol Anderson, branch distribution director for Scotland at TSB, said: ldquoOur customers use banking services in dferent ways and that is why we try to adapt our offer to deliver them the best possible service, however they choose to bank.ldquoThis means investment in both branches and digital channels.ldquoWith fewer people using [the branches], we are reducing the number of hours.ldquoOur TSB Partners will be working with our customers to support them as we make this change.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of Dunbar Community Council, felt it was disappointing to see a unit on High Street not being fully utilised.Mrs Swan said: ldquoI think all banks are making decisions about how they can best operate financially.ldquoThey must have worked out their best business case is to work two days a week.ldquoI suspect some of the customers will find it sufficiently inconvenient that they will switch banks. We, as a community council, are aware of lots of people who did switch from the Royal Bank of Scotland to Bank of Scotland [when Dunbarrsquos RBS closed last year].ldquoI think it is plainly unfortunate to have a unit on High Street that is not operational five days a week.

title: chance-for-public-to-have-a-look-at-major-plans-at-dunbar-golf-club
story: The plans ndash which are an update of proposals submitted a decade ago and would complement the existing golf course ndash also include a new driving range, a nine-hole golf course, a golf academy and practice facilities.Tony Thomas, who is representing Dunbar Golf Club and CALA Management Ltd, which are behind the plans, visited the townrsquos community council ahead of the public exhibition, which takes place in the townrsquos Dunmuir Hotel between pm and pm tomorrow.Mr Thomas said alterations to the original plans, which were approved in , meant a new planning application had to be submitted.Now, amended plans have been drawn up, with hopes that a planning application could be with East Lothian Council, which would likely decide the fate of the proposals, by the autumn. Regardless of whether the plans are approved, golf will continue to be played on the -hole championship course.Mr Thomas, from East Lintonrsquos APT Planning and Development, said: ldquoIf we get the application in by September, something as relatively complex as this,we get permission this time next year we will be doing well.ldquoThe first houses would be a year later and then the clubhouse built by  for the clubhouse to opens its doors in .ldquoThe last houses would be  months on from that.The majority of the houses would be built towards Deer Park Cemetery, with about  units being built on the site of the current clubhouse.Under the plans, a new clubhouse would be built, with access coming from the A, and a nine-hole course built to the north-west, and a driving range to the east.The changes will mean a slight alteration to the layout of the course.The development will not include affordable housing as it is part of an enabling development. However, Mr Thomas stressed more than pound, would go to East Lothian Council in education contributions.Provisional designs for the properties, which are expected to be between three and five-bedroom in size, will be included in display boards at the exhibition.Details regarding the size of the hotel are still being worked out but historically the proposal was for a building with between  and  rooms.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, felt there were issues which could be addressed to enhance the proposals.She said: ldquoI just feel a sense of disappointment that the developers, who have such a wonderful opportunity, do not seem to take the opportunity to build more contemporary, innovative housing. That is my regret. It is a fantastic site but the sense of what we are going to get is a repeat of the Cala homes at Beveridge Row.Mrs Swan also noted a lot of people used the land at Deer Park for recreation.She said a previous public meeting, when the community council was consulting about East Lothian Councilrsquos local development plan, had highlighted a desire for improved connections throughout the town.She added: ldquoThe public meeting said it was really, really important to ensure there are really good pedestrian and cycle links back into the town wherever possible.

title: north-berwick-institution-sula-ii-is-retired
story: The Sula II, a much-loved wooden passenger boat, has ceased her summer tours around the Bass Rock and neighbouring islands after more than four decades of sailings.The clinker-built vessel is making her way to Southampton after being sold by owner Duncan MacRae.Mr MacRae, who purchased the vessel about  months ago, said: ldquoThe Sula II is a very old vessel and will struggle to comply with new safety regulations coming into force next year from the MCA .ldquoAs I take safety very seriously, I had the chance to sell the Sula II and she has now moved down to Southampton.ldquoSula III has now been ordered and purpose-built in Scotland to the highest modern standards and will be operational by next Easter.ldquoFor this season I am just about to secure the use of another vessel to keep the excellent Bass Rock sailings available for the public.The boat was originally purchased in the s by legendary North Berwick boatman and fisherman Fred Marr, who had been working on passenger launches from North Berwick throughout the s and s.She was the second boat he had bought for the purpose of tours, the first onebeing slightly old with a paraffin engine, so it was sold and Sula II replaced it.Pat Macaulay, Fredrsquos daughter, said: ldquoMy father purchased Sula II in  after seeing an advert in the Fishing News. This boat was originally called the Janet and was built in Norfolk.ldquoThe name Sula was chosen because it is the Latin name for the gannet, the bird that made Bass Rock a world-renowned bird sanctuary.The boat took tourists and locals out to sea from North Berwick on the Bass Rock tours under the Marr family up until , when Fredrsquos son Chris retired after  yearsrsquo sailing.Fred himself had retired in . He passed away in  and there is a plaque in his memory at North Berwick harbour.Sula II has seen many celebrities and dignitaries over her years, including Prince Charles, Brigitte Bardot, Sir David Attenborough, Alan Titchmarsh and Bill McLaren.Pat, who now lives on the Isle of Lewis, said: ldquoI have been contemplating for some time putting together a scrapbook of memories, photos, thoughts and reminisces from the many hundreds of people who enjoyed boat trips aboard Sula II over the years.ldquoSula II is etched into my heart and bloodstream, as is Bass Rock, itrsquos a very special place.To get in touch with Pat with memories from the Sula II, email patandthesula@gmail

title: long-serving-nursery-nurse-praised-as-she-retires
story: Susan Walker stepped down from her role at Macmerry Primary School shortly before the schools broke up for the Easter break.Jenner Welsh, who works at the school, said: ldquoSusan is known for her love of children, patience, organisation, kind manner and her commitment to the children and their families.ldquoShe has seen many colleagues come and go within the school and nursery and made many special friends along the way.ldquoSusan leaves us to embark on some travel, spend time with her family and take time to enjoy her many hobbies.ldquoShe will also be the newest member of the lsquoladies who lunch clubrsquo made from previous Macmerry retired staff.ldquoWe all wish her a well-deserved, long and enjoyable retirement.Susan lives to the east of Haddington with her husband.

title: Iain Macwhirter  As May goes down for the third time  the road to Brexit just got a whole lot longer
story: The Prime Minister has behaved asshe had a thumping Commons majority when in fact she is a minority leader of an unstable coalition. Even after the Damascene conversion of arch-Brexiter Jacob Rees-Mogg, who used to described her deal as ldquovassalage, her final attempt to get a stripped-down Withdrawal Agreement through Parliament failed on Friday by a substantial majority. You have to give May full marks for her consistency: everything she touches turns to dust, even her own resignation.But thatrsquos by the by. As everyone has been saying: we are where we are. And where we are is extremely uncomfortable. Brexiters are gearing up to have a belly laugh at the opposition MPs, who will do their best throughout the coming week to find a compromise. Who do they think they are  Playing at being a provisional government  ldquoItrsquos like allowing the whelk stall to be run by the whelks, according to the Tory MP Sir Bill Cash. Butno-one  is able to run the eponymous stall, then all power to the whelks.Last weekrsquos indicative votes suggested that MPs are broadly in favour of a Brexit that keeps Britain in the EUrsquos economic loop while leaving the political institutions. Curiously, the SNP, who have been arguing for soft Brexit in two white papers and an election manesto, decided not to vote for the ious options, even the Norway model that they have long extolled. The SNP did, however, vote for the proposal from the Labour MP Margaret Beckett for a confirmatory ballot, and this option got the largest number of votes, much to everyonersquos surprise. This must be a serious possibility now that Parliament has failed to resolve the Brexit conundrum.However, this is not a Peoplersquos Vote as some have styled it. A confirmatory vote is not a rerun of the  referendum, but strictly a chance for voters to give their views on whatever deal Parliament agrees . The Kyle Wilson Amendment originally envisaged putting the Prime Ministerrsquos deal to a popular vote, assuming it was passed by Parliament. However, this confirmatory referendum might be dficult to schedule because it could collide with three other elections: a Tory leadership election, the European elections and a General Election. Brenda from Bristol will be in despair.EvenMPs fail to come up with a working compromise, they can still block a no-deal Brexit. The majority against leaving the EU without a deal is overwhelming. This means May, or her successor, will have to go cap-in-hand to Brussels in the next few days and request another, longer delay to Article . This would mean Britain participating in the European elections in May, which excites the Independent Group of Tory and Labour rebels, but is looked upon with dread by the main parties. Brussels too is worried about populist contagion spreading to other EU countries like Italy, but they are legally bound to make British participation a condition of any further extension to AVoter wrath, particularly in Labourrsquos leave constituencies, could lead to a dramatic revival of Nigel Faragersquos Ukip, or worse. The Svengali behind the  Vote Leave campaign, Dominic Cummings, is gearing up for the fight and reportedly suggesting a new party to fight for the right to leave. ldquoTell them again is the favoured slogan. The European elections might themselves turn into a kind of second referendum on Brexit.The Tories will presumably have a new leader by then, since Theresa May will surely go now there is to be the long extension she has resolutely opposed. Mind you, it is impossible to guess the Prime Ministerrsquos thought processes. She said she would goher withdrawal deal passed on Friday. But her gambit didnrsquot work. Even the opportunity to dispense with Mayrsquos services was not sufficient inducement for the Democratic Unionist Party to come on board. The joke doing the rounds last week was that she tried to fall on her sword and missed.But these things have a momentum of their own, and the Tory leadership election has already begun. Boris Johnson is the narrow frontrunner, but that could change. He might win the membership, but under Tory rules the parliamentary party has to agree the two candidates put to a postal ballot. The remainers in the Tory benches might use this as an opportunity to foil the hard Brexiters by keeping Boris off the list.Of course, what should happen when a government fails to get its most important legislation through Parliament is not a leadership election, but a General Election. The government cannot govern and, even with the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, this should lead to a General Election via a vote of no confidence. Some Conservatives might prefer to fight a General Election than European elections they had promised would never take place. But events are now out of everyonersquos control.Everyone, that is, except the EU, which now holds Britainrsquos future in the balance. Itrsquos trying not to crow about Britainrsquos abject national humiliation, but the , not the UK Parliament, will now decide the UKrsquos immediate future: deal or no deal. If MPs agree this week to back a soft Brexit involving the customs union and alignment with the single market, Brussels has promised to fast-track it in a matter of days. But the alternative, a long extension, will also suit the European Union.That means more money from Britainrsquos budget contribution, and serves as a warning to other EU countries about the dangers of trying to leave the Union. It also holds out the possibility of Britain remaining in the EU,a referendum is eventually staged.Well, that remains to be seen. What is perhaps more likely is that Britain gets stuck indefinitely in a long extension. It emerged last week that the Democratic Unionist Party, which again voted against Mayrsquos withdrawal deal, could live with a long extension. Indeed, they signalled that they could live with a customs union ndash as long as it ensured no border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. The DUP may be Brexiters, but they are ardent Unionists first.A soft Brexit may now be the best way of keeping the UK together. But it should be put to the people in a confirmatory vote,for no other reason than this was not what most people thought they were voting for in . MPs have the opportunity to decide this tomorrow.How and why Theresa May failed to seek the only kind of Brexit that could get through Parliament will be left for historians to judge. One of her own Cabinet ministers, quoted on BBC Newsnight, gave the provisional verdict: ldquoShersquos the sole architect of this mess because of her inability to engage in the most basic human interaction. Who says personalities donrsquot matter in great historical events

title: former-snp-mp-natalie-mcgarry-admits-embezzling-25000
story: Natalie McGarry, , faced three charges of embezzlement and a charge that she refused to give police the passcode for a mobile phone they had seized.McGarry, who represented Glasgow East but did not seek re-election in , admitted two of the charges when she appeared at Glasgow Sherf Court on Wednesday and the Crown accepted not guilty pleas to the other two.She embezzled pound, from Women for Independence in her role as treasurer of the organisation.Read more:Former SNP MP Natalie McGarry sacks counsel days before embezzlement trialShe transferred money raised through fundraising events into her personal bank accounts and failed to transfer charitable donations to Perth and Kinross food bank and to Positive Prison, Positive Future between April ,  and November , .She also used cheques drawn on the Women for Independence bank account to deposit money into her own account.McGarry also admitted embezzling pound,. in the course of her role as treasurer, secretary and convener of the Glasgow Regional Association of the SNP between April ,  and August , .She was elected as an SNP member in  but resigned the party whip following the emergence of fraud allegations - which she denied at the time - continuing in Parliament as an independent.She was charged by police in  over alleged fraud relating to potential missing funds from Women for Independence, which was set up in the run-up to the  Scottish referendum, and the SNPs Glasgow Regional Association.McGarry represented herself when she appeared at court on Wednesday.

title: new-concert-hall-plan-for-edinburgh-given-green-light
story: The scheme for the new venue has been given planning permission by the City of Edinburgh Council.The venue, in a space behind the Royal Bank of Scotlands building in Edinburghs New Town, has been designed by architect Sir David Chipperfield.The Dunard Centre will have a ,-seat auditorium, a -seat studio and a large foyer for all-day, informal performance, and is likely to open in .Sir Ewan Brown, Chairman of Impact Scotland, the body behind the venue, said: "Todayrsquos decision is tremendous news for the city and turns the ambition for a world-class centre for music and performance, into a reality."I am particularly pleased to announce today that the official name of the venue will be Dunard Centre supported by Royal Bank of Scotland, this is in recognition of the huge contribution Carol Grigor has made to this project through the charitable trust Dunard Fund."We now have the opportunity to create an exciting new venue for everyone, in a building to be proud of."Sir David Chipperfield said: "This will be a public building that relates to Edinburgh on a civic scale by both fitting in and standing out in order to perform an important social and cultural role in a city with strong established cultural traditions."Its location is just off St Andrew Square, in the centre of Edinburgh.: Plans for new concert hall for Edinburgh revealedThe project is receiving pound million through the Edinburgh City Region Deal, with pound million from the UK Government, pound million from the Scottish Government, and pound million from City of Edinburgh Council.All other funding is being met privately, most signicantly from Dunard Fund who, in addition to a substantial donation, are "underwriting any capital cost overruns and annual deficits of the centre in the first  years of operation."The leader of the city council, Adam McVey, said: "The city region deal has given us the first opportunity for more than  years to create a new concert hall in Edinburgh."Itrsquos a hugely exciting time and now that the designs have planning permission, the project can move forward."The creation of the Concert hall will provide an excellent new venue and home for the Scottish Chamber Orchestra and be another exiting development on St Andrew Sq. "None of it would be possible without our ambitious city deal or the generosity of philanthropists like Carol Grigor."Together, wersquore opening up an exciting new chapter in Edinburghrsquos already thriving cultural scene to help more of our residents to take part in and enjoy the arts.It will be the new home of the Scottish Chamber Orchestra and a principal venue for the Edinburgh International Festival.

title: scottish-teachers-teaching-three-courses-in-the-same-class
story: The Scottish Parliaments education committee heard controversial "tri-level" teaching was a growing problem - with concerns it led to lower standards.Last summer, The Herald revealed schools across Scotland had more than  vacancies just weeks before the new school year.The research showed shortages in key subject areas such as science, maths, computing, languages and home economics, as well as in rural areas.: Narrowing of curriculum "risking generation of pupils"William Hardie, policy advice manager for the Royal Society of Edinburgh, told the committee multi-course teaching was a particular issue in the sciences.He said: "Whilst courses may have similar titles, a National  in physics will be very dferent from a National  course in physics, but quite often they will be taught together which can obviously impact on the quality of teachinga teacher has got to teach quite dferent classes."Sometimes that can be exacerbated by having to teach National , National  and Higher in the same classes."This obviously touches on the dficulties of recruiting subject specialist teachers, particularly in the sciences and computing science, which means that in some schools multi-course teaching may well be the only way the school can timetable those courses to allow them to be run."Professor Jim Scott, from the School of Education at Dundee University, said the extent to which tri-level teaching was now prevalent was a major concern.He said: "It tends to be prevalent in minority subjects or in smaller schools, but it is a genuine issue. With the sciences it should be a no-no, but it does seem to be prevalent in quite a lot of the smaller subjects."It seems to be a growing problem. Some sources indicate this is down to local authority staffing levels, some of them indicate it is the headteacher or senior management teams view of the curriculum and some say it comes from the principal teacher who wants to do it this way to make space and time.": Warning as subject choice continues to declineLabour MSP Johann Lamont asked to what extent the requirement for multi-level teaching was built into teacher training to ensure staff were equipped for the practice.Dr Alan Britton, senior lecturer in education at Glasgow University, said initial teacher education "did what it could" to prepare teachers for the dferent scenarios they would encounter.He said: "We prepare them as best we can andthey are subject specialists in secondary then we will try to prepare them for the reality of multi-level teaching."Would any teacher actively choose to construct their teaching and learning in that way  The reality is that most teachers,given a choice between multi-level teaching or not, they wouldnt want it."The warnings come after a survey by the Scottish Secondary Teachersrsquo Association found  per cent of members were teaching classes containing pupils aiming at two dferent qualications and a quarter had pupils studying three.A separate study in  by the Royal Society of Chemistry found  per cent of National  chemistry classes had pupils studying for other qualications and  per cent of Highers being taught were multi-course.Asked how well they felt able to support pupils in multi-course classes,  per cent of teachers in National  and National  classes responded either ldquonot at all or ldquonot very well.MSPs also heard concerns over evidence given at the last committee meeting by Gayle Gorman, the new chief executive of curriculum and inspection body Education Scotland.She said earlier this month that the link between an areas wealth and the number of Higher subjects on offer was not as big a concern as some thought.: Exam chaos looms after strike ballot at SQAThis was because extra government funding for schools in disadvantaged areas and "consortia arrangements" where pupils can travel to other schools to sit a wider range of qualications were proving effective.Mr Scott said: "I have to say I was surprised. I found myself wonderingI lived in the same educational world."Mr Hardie added: "If Education Scotland is simply saying there is no link and not substantiating that then it may be an area this committee may want to follow up with them to seethey have data which shows a dferent answer."

title: new-festival-to-celebrate-edvard-griegs-scottish-lineage
story: Now the music of Norwegian composer Edd Grieg and his links to Scotland - his great-grandfather Alexander Greig was a Scot - is to be celebrated in a new festival in Aberdeenshire.The Grieg Society of Scotland, which last year oversaw the conservation of the historic gravestone of the composers Scottish ancestors, are planning the new festival as part of a series of activities to raise further awareness of the links between Scotland and the composer.Grieg, who lived from  to , was one of the leading composers of the Romantic era, his repertoire - such as his famous music for Peer Gynt and his piano concerto - a standard in orchestras across the world.This week the Grieg Society, which is still endeavouring the secure the future of the gravestone of his ancestors in Rathen Old Kirkyard, near Fraserburgh, Aberdeenshire, have released a new film and D model of the stone.Dr Sally Garden, honorary director of the society, said that it is now considering a new festival, to last a day or more, to celebrate the links between Scotland, Grieg, and Norway.She added: "Thematically, the festival will follow the inspirations of Edd Grieg and his we, singer Nina Grieg ndash linking music, landscape and language ndash inspirations we have a natural feel for in Scotland, not least in the linguistically fertile North East."We hope to have a main musical event featuring a lsquoname from Norwayrsquo, an event for children, and a number of other activities."We have discussed with the Church and local community plans for an initial one day or day and a half festival, in the first instance to see how things go, and what could be established."Therersquos a lot of general support for the ideas wersquove shared, but it will take time, working closely with the community, to translate concept into practical plan."Griegs great grandfather settled in Norway in , and became a businessman in Bergen.The composer once said: "My great-grandfather was a Scot, andmy works have achieved a popularity which is incomprehensible to me, the reason is surely not only to be found in the national element, but perhaps rather in the fusion of cosmopolitan and national elements."The gravestone in Rathen Old Kirkyard commemorates Griegrsquos great, great grandparents, John Greig and his we Ann Milne, two of whose sons, Alexander - the composerrsquos great grandfather - and James emigrated to Norway.The conservation effort last year was carried out by Spectrum Heritage, with support from the Heritage Lottery Fund, and Bergen philanthropist Per Grieg, of the Grieg family.Johanne Grieg Kippenbroeck, the Honorary President, Grieg Society of Scotland and member of the Grieg family said: "The Griegs in Norway are very proud of Edd Grieg, of course, but we are also proud of our Scottish ancestry."The job that has been done to literally rescue the gravestone of John Greig and Ann Milne, our and Edd Griegrsquos ancestors in Scotland, is marvellous."Another year and it would probably have been too late. The Grieg Society of Scotland does a wonderful job both for Grieg ndash and also for Bergen and Norway."The society hope the new film and D model will "provide an accessible and enjoyable resource for everyone to understand and value the North Sea network of family and cultural ties which still, today, links Scotland with her Scandinavian neighbours."Dr Garden said thatthe conservation effort of last year had been any later, some of the damage to the stone would have been irretrievable.She added: "We have done our best to hinder further deterioration by protecting as far as possible against surface damp. Aberdeenshire Council and Historic Environment Scotland have also been very helpful, within the constraints of what they can do, and we will monitor the stonersquos condition going forward to seeanything more radical needs to be done."The most important outcome of our conservation work is that we have been able to create the first definitive record of the stonersquos inscription, about which there has been ambiguity and a few details missed over the years."The Society will host a weekend of community workshops at Rathen, in June.Councillor Charles Buchan, of Aberdeenshire Council, said: ldquoThe Grieg Society of Scotland, and its director, Dr Sally Garden, has done so much to bring back into the public awareness the composer Edd Grieg, and his connections with the village of Rathen, and surrounding farms."In particular, they have to be commended for having spent immense efforts on conservation work in the old Rathen Kirkyard, including the restoration of the family grave, which will be a huge addition to the heritage tourism of Rathen and the North-East.Clara Molina Sanchez, of Spectrum Heritage, said: ldquoNew imaging techniques like photogrammetry and RTIhelp us enhance details of the surface of cultural heritage objects which we would not be able to see with the naked eye. These tools help conservators record the state of objects, and to engage with dferent audiences, as in the case of this gravestone, from Scotland, Norway, and all across the globe."We are very much looking forward to passing this knowledge on to the community at Rathen, especially to the younger generation."

title: nicola-sturgeon-planning-indyref2-before-2021-ballot
story: She said a new Holyrood bill would pave the way for ldquoa choice between Brexit and a future for Scotland as an independent European nation before the Scottish election in .The framework legislation, which the First Minister will ask MSPs to pass this year, will set out the rules and regulations for a new vote.However, she admitted the UK Government would first have to give consent, by transferring powers under a so-called Section  order, before a referendum could take place.With Theresa May making it clear she will refuse any such request, the Tories dubbed Ms Sturgeonrsquos plan ldquothe bill to nowhere and a waste of taxpayersrsquo time and money.SNP sources suggested a minority Labour administration under Jeremy Corbyn might permit a vote, but any leader would be reluctant to have their premiership dominated by constitutional issues in light of Brexit.Ms Sturgeon was also accused of ldquodevaluing her office by using it to promote independence and reassure her impatient activists before this weekendrsquos SNP conference.After the statement, Ms Sturgeonrsquos husband, the SNP chief executive Peter Murrell, launched a fundraising website called yes.scot, which had previously belonged to the failed Yes Scotland campaign of .It said the First Minister had given ldquonew impetus to our campaigning and appealed for cash to help the SNP win the EU election on May .It also asked for money to send all . million households an economic case for leaving the UK called An Independent Scotland: Household Guide.SNP members are due to decide on Saturday which currency anindependent Scotland would use.In a coordinated move, a new ldquonon-party, civic organisation for independence called Voices forScotland will be launched today by the Scottish Independence Convention.It says its aim is ldquobig, open conversations about Scotlandrsquos future.But in a sign of ision within the wider Yes movement over the efficacy of Mrs Sturgeonrsquos plan, the influential pro-independence website Wings Over Scotland was scathing.It called her bill a ldquostalling exercise designed to appease SNP members by holding out the hope of a referendum before , while offering nothing concrete to bring it about.Author Stuart Campbell said: ldquoIn short, nothing changed. The SNP is still frozen in the headlights, hoping for some sort of deliverance to show up from an external source.Scottish Socialist Party co-convener Colin Fox, who was part of YesScotland in , added: ldquoThe First Minister continues to preicate over IndyRef and seems at a loss to make a more compelling case for Independence than hitherto. It looks more like a tool of party management than a step to winning independence.Ms Sturgeon also announced aCitizensrsquo Assembly, based on examples in Ireland, in which a cross-section of Scots under an independent chair would debate Scotlandrsquos future. But she failed to sayit would shape the next independence prospectus.Brexit Secretary Michael Russell will also ask the other party leaders at Holyrood to enter cross-party talks on devolving more powers.The First Minister urged the parties to consider the challenges posed by Brexit ldquoopenly, not dig in behind a ldquofixed position, but the Tories said they would boycott the exercise.Backed by a - vote of MSPs, Ms Sturgeon first requested a Section  order for a second referendum in March , but Mrs May refused.After SNP losses in the snap  general election, Ms Sturgeon ldquoreset her plans, and promised a ldquoprecisetimescale on Indyref by autumn of , when the terms of Brexit were supposed to be clear. However she repeatedly delayed an announcement because of Brexit uncertainty.Although that uncertainty remains, Ms Sturgeon said she could not wait ldquoindefinitely to protect Scotlandrsquos interests.She said Brexit threatened Scotlandrsquos economy and its workforce, and hence the tax revenues needed to pay for vital services such as health and education.She did not offer a date, or explain how she could extract a Section  order from London, but said preparations needed to get underway to allow a vote by .She claimed most Scots wanted a vote on independence ldquoalthough opinions y on timing. Recent polls suggest most Scots oppose independence and oppose a vote in the short-term, although a majority would accept one after a decade.She told MSPs: ldquoOne point of clarity has surely emerged over the past three years, even for the most ardent opponent of Scottish independence: the Westminster system of government simply does not serve Scotlandrsquos interests and the devolution settlement in its current form is now seen to be utterly inadequate to the task of protecting those interests. In other words, the status quo is broken.She went on: ldquoMy job as First Minister is to reach a judgment, not simply in my partyrsquos interest but in the national interest. In doing so, a key priority is ensuring that we learn the lessons of Brexit.ldquoTo rush into an immediate decision before a Brexit path has been determined would not allow an informed choice to be made. However,we are to safeguard Scotlandrsquos interests, we cannot wait indefinitely.ldquoThat is why I consider that a choice between Brexit and a future for Scotland as an independent European nation should be offered later in the letime of this Parliament.ldquoIf Scotland is taken out of the EU, the option of a referendum on independence within that timescale must be open to us. That would be our route to avoiding the worst of the damage that Brexit will do.However she acknowledged Holyrood could not hold currently a referendum.She said: ldquoWe do not need a transfer of power such as a Section  order to pass such a framework bill, though we would need it to put beyond doubt or challenge our ability to apply the bill to an independence referendum.ldquoThe UK Governmentrsquos current position is that it will not agree to transfer power, but I believe that that position will prove to be unsustainable.ldquoBy making progress with primary legislation first, we will not squander valuable time now in a standoff with a UK Government that might soon be out of office.ldquoWe will seek agreement to a transfer of power at an appropriate point during or shortly after the billrsquos passage, on the basis that it will be exercised when this Parliament - and no other - considers it right to offer the people of Scotland a choice.Western Isles SNP MP Angus Brendan MacNeil predicted a referendum in autumn , telling the Herald it was good that the First Minister had ldquoput the focus back on independence after appearing to prioritise a Peoplersquos Vote.His SNP colleague, Tommy Sheppard, the MP for Edinburgh East, added: ldquoThere is no point waiting until disaster happens before planning how to survive it.ldquoIndependence offers Scotland the best way to survive Brexit and,nothing changes at Westminster, we need to be ready to move fast.A Downing Street spokesperson said the  No vote should be respected, as both sides said they would do that and ldquothat is what needs to happen.Acting Scottish Tory leader Jackson Carlaw said that, despite her spokesman describing it as ldquoinclusive, the First Ministerrsquos speech was ldquoinherently isive.He said: ldquoAstonishingly, the First Minister thinks the way in which we come together is for the people of Scotland to be plunged into another isive referendum within the next  months.ldquoIt is a ridiculous and even disgraceful skewing of her priorities with the real priorities of the country.ldquoThe SNPrsquos plan is clearly to ide families, workplaces and communities all over again, and for the foreseeable future. That is not what the majority of Scotland wants.ldquoPeople have had enough of constitutional politics and ision. Yet, with the SNP, more of this is now inevitable.Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard said: ldquoThe timing of this statement is nothing to do with where we are in the chaos of Brexit. It has nothing to do with where the polls are on the creation of a separate Scottish state.ldquoThe timing of the statement has everything to do with the First Ministerrsquos party conference taking place in just three daysrsquo time. The First Minister is using this parliamentary  as a party  and, in doing that, she is devaluing the office that she holds.ldquoThe First Minister knows fine well that there is no evidence whatsoever that the people of Scotland want another independence referendum, and that is no wonder when the chaos of Brexit throws into sharp relief the challenges of leaving a political and economic union.Scottish LibDem leader Willie Rennie added: ldquoThe First Minister hasnrsquot done the one decent thing that people in Scotland want her to do, which is to take her campaign for independence off the table.ldquoNicola Sturgeon should look at the damage caused by Brexit and the ision it has caused and learn a lesson. Breaking up is hard to do.The last thing the country needs is another isive independence campaign. We should not repeat the mistakes of Brexit. The First Minister should make it stop now.Greens MSP Alison Johnstone said: ldquoWe have always believed that Scotlandrsquos future should be in Scotlandrsquos hands, as an independent nation at the heart of Europe. The Brexit shambles has only confirmed our belief that we would be far better governing ourselves.She welcomed the Citizensrsquo Assembly, but warned it must not ldquosimply be a talking shop and said her party would put pressure on SNP ministers to ensure the new body shaped government policy.Scottish Secretary David Mundell said: ldquoPeople in Scotland voted decisively in  to remain part of the UK, on a promise the referendum would settle the issue for a generation.ldquoInstead of respecting that result, Nicola Sturgeon continues to press for isive constitutional change when it is clear that most people in Scotland do not want another independence referendum. The UK Government will stand up for them.ldquoNicola Sturgeon needs to listen to the views of the Scottish people and concentrate on improving Scotlandrsquos economy and schools, not continually trying to orchestrate upheaval and ision.Caithness LibDem MP Jamie Stone said the First Minister was the ldquohostage of the extremist wing of her party.Edinburgh South Labour MP Ian Murray added: ldquoNationalism is killing our country but the SNP will not stop until it gets what it wants at any cost. Itrsquos a grievo-max agenda.

title: letters-it-would-be-an-affront-to-deny-us-a-referendum
story: If Scotland is indeed a separate entity which centuries ago entered a voluntary union with England, is not simply a subjugated colony, it should be able to leave the Union at will without seeking permission. It is unconscionable that a referendum result, whatever way it went, would not be accepted unconditionally by the other members of the Union. That the Prime Minister can simply dismiss the possibility of a second referendum is an outrageous denial of democracy to all Scots whether or not they support independence. That an embattled and unpopular Mrs May can do so without discussion of the matter formally in Westminster simply demonstrates how undemocratic our form of governance actually is. If the people want it we should be able hold a referendum on the subject every Tuesday afternoon who will stop us  What sanctions would be inflicted on Scotland to prevent it happening or in the aftermath of a "leave" majority  Would they send the troops and tanks back to Glasgow The Brexit referendum received  per cent support of the eligible pool of voters and is used as justication for leaving the EU it follows that a simple majority in any future referendum on Scottish independence will suffice. That is assuming that Bumbling Boris the Red Corbyn or whatever Unionista takes Mrs Mayrsquos place feels it is in Englandrsquos interest to let us ldquosweaty socks put down our deep-fried Mars Bars and sober-up for long enough to repeat the exercise.David J Crawford, Whittingehame Court  Great Western Road, Glasgow.Read more: Letters: SNP priorities not those of Scottish votersA WEEK is a long time in politics. It is almost five years since the independence referendum of . Since then many of the Conservative voters in my elderly category have gone and there is a  to -year-old cohort who could not vote in . Many who voted against independence did so to remain in the EU: that was before Brexit. Both Gerald Edwards and Alexander McKaythink that the independence and Brexit games are over: Dr Edwards evades the fact that the people of Scotland voted against Brexit, Mr McKay thinks that the majority of Scots are in favour of the Union ndash for "are" read "were" in , not necessarily now.There are recent precedents for re-runs: the Prime Ministers multiple attempts to push the Brexit deal through Parliament and the prospect of UK participation in the EU elections on May . Whatever the chaos of Westminster and the Brexit process has demonstrated, it is that nothing is set in stone and that change happens.Colin Campbell,Braeside, Shuttle Street, Kilbarchan.SO we wait many months for Nicola Sturgeon to tell us that she wants to hold another referendum before  ndash when she risks losing the nationalist majority in Holyrood. And on Tuesday Downing Street reiterated that it would not grant a Section  order, which would enable indyref to be held. So nothing new from either side.That Ms Sturgeons announcement is days before the SNP party conference is no coincidence. But I suspect the party faithful will realise this announcement furthers their cause not a jot.Martin Redfern,Woodcroft Road, Edinburgh.THE political situation in the United Kingdom is a veritable Pandoras Box of misunderstandings, unravellings, hubris, nostalgia and gross incompetence.It truly takes a careful observer patience and acuity to work their way through the morass.Observers from outside the UK watch with disbelief as the Conservative Party tries to hold itself together against the assaults of its internal and external opponents.The disdain that has been shown by the Conservative leadership to the European negotiators is only equalled by that shown to the other nations of the UK.Now in Scotland, we find ourselves on the cusp of a new stage of political development which will go forward despite the opponents mantra of "too wee, too small, too poor".The previous three years have shown such levels of Government incompetence and inhumanity that there has been a clear sht in Scottish self-awareness. Despite the chorus of hostility against the Scottish Government by all the major parties who support the Union, it is being seen by many outside the UK that Westminster is a busted flush.The Conservative Partys policies of the two-child family, the bedroom tax, the hostile environment of the Home Office to the Windrush generation and other BAME families have exposed Westminster as deeply uncaring. The treatment of low-paid British workers and benefit recipients has been beyond belief for someone like me who was born at the end of the Second World War.Nicola Sturgeon has been promoted by many as a competent and humane leader. She has throughout the Brexit negotiationstried to find solutions that embraced the economic and social needs of the whole of the UK and of European citizens of the UK and UK residents in Europe.She is not without faults. Her support for the Growth Commission has caused many pro-independence supporters to feel disappointment. There are many of us who want to see the great opportunities that control of our own economy and currency can bring.The currency debateis a healthy one. It will determine the nature of the Scottish economy after independence.Let us ensure that we begin to build a country we can all be proud of.Maggie Chetty, Woodend Drive, Glasgow.JAMES Campbellcould not be more wrong. Far from having a banana republic currency, a Scots pound would be stronger than sterling. The top-secret McCrone Report of the mid-s said that Scotland would have one of the strongest currencies in the world. It would still be strong today because Scotland has a balance of trade surplus, while the UK runs a deficit of around pound billion a month. Sterling is the weak currency.As far as the EU being a ldquotiny market, it is more than eight times the UK market. Does Mr Campbell really want to cut us off from the big market Ian Macdonald, Maxwell Avenue, Bearsden.

title: social-security-secretary-hails-swift-progress-on-benefits-move
story: The Social SecurityBill was passed unanimously at the Scottish Parliament on April  .It is moving responsibility for  welfare benefits to Scotland, ultimately worth about pound billion a year, in the ldquosingle biggest transfer of powers since devolution began.:MSPs to hear calls for Universal Credit reformSocial Security Secretary Shirley-Anne Somerville said that pound million in benefit payments has been made by the Scottish Government to more than , people in the past  months.Social Security Scotland has established a head office in Dundee and a second site in Glasgow, with around  people employed across both bases.Ms Somerville said: ldquoOver the past year, we have put the biggest transfer of powers since devolution into practice.ldquoProgress has been swt and I am delighted within a year we have both the legislation and infrastructure of Scotlandrsquos newest public service.:Scotlands new benefits agency spends more than poundk on staff travel expenses#ldquoWe can be pleased with the success we have achieved so far and that Social Security Scotland is now delivering for the people of Scotland every day, with much more to come."Social Security Secretary Shirley-Anne SomervilleShe added: ldquoThere are challenges ahead, and also many opportunities. To increase the financial support to those who need it and to ensure our social security system treats people with respect and dignity.:Secrecy row as SNP quietly drop devolved benefit#ldquoI have laid out my plans for the benefits that will be introduced this year and for the future delivery of devolved benefits.ldquoResponsibility for all devolved benefits, including their funding, will be with the Scottish Government from April  next year, with the rollout of disability assistance starting shortly after.ldquoIt is through disability assistance we can make the biggest dference to the largest number of people, particularly through reform of an assessments system that causes stress and anxiety. And at all times involving people in how we do that, designing a system with people and for people.

title: competition-watchdog-blocks-sainsburys-asda-merger
story: In its final report into the deal, theCompetition and Markets Authorityfound that it would lead to increased prices in stores, online and at petrol stations across the UK.:Sainsburys - Asda merger at risk after competition watchdog warningShoppers and motorists would be ldquoworse offSainsburyrsquos and Walmart-owned Asda were to merge, the CMA said, adding that a tie-up would lead to price rises, reductions in the quality and range of products or a poorer overall retail experience.The watchdog claimed that the deal would have resulted in a ldquosubstantial lessening of competition at both a national and local level for people shopping in supermarkets.Wersquove blocked the Sainsburyrsquos   Asda merger after finding that it would lead to:# Higher prices for groceries and fuel# Less choice and worse quality of products## A poor shopping experienceRead more: https:t.co FrOpssqwS pic lJQtkBbeCmdash Competition  Markets AuthorityApril , Stuart McIntosh, chairman of the CMA inquiry group, said: ldquoItrsquos our responsibility to protect the millions of people who shop at Sainsburyrsquos and Asda every week.ldquoFollowing our in-depth investigation, we have found this deal would lead to increased prices, reduced quality and choice of products, or a poorer shopping experience for all of their UK shoppers.ldquoWe have concluded that there is no effective way of addressing our concerns, other than to block the merger.Sainsburyrsquos boss Mike Coupe said that the decision effectively takes pound billion out of customersrsquo pockets.Prior to Thursdayrsquos decision, Sainsburyrsquos and Walmart-owned Asda had offered to sell up to  stores as part of efforts to address competition concerns, and claimed that shoppers would be deprived of lower prices should it be blocked.The duo had pledged to make a number of post-merger commitments, had the deal been approved. It included investing pound billion a year in lowering prices by the third year of the deal completing, equating to a % cut on everyday items.:Sainsburyrsquos and Asda in talks over poundbn mergerMr Coupe said on Thursday: ldquoThe specic reason for wanting to merge was to lower prices for customers. The CMArsquos conclusion that we would increase prices post-merger ignores the dynamic and highly competitive nature of the UK grocery market. The CMA is today effectively taking pound billion out of customersrsquo pockets.Sainsburyrsquos, Walmart and Asda have now mutually agreed to terminate the transaction.A merger between the duo, the UKrsquos number two and three supermarkets, would have created a supermarket titan bigger than Tesco with revenues of pound billion and a network of , Sainsburyrsquos, Asda and Argos stores.But fears had been expressed that suppliers could get squeezed as a result, with the tie-up giving the merged entity increased buying power.The move to reject the tie-up marks the first major decision the CMA has made since the appointment of former Tory MP Andrew Tyrie as chairman.Best known for his role as head of the influential Treasury Select Committee, Mr Tyrie gained a reputation as an effective inquisitor of corporate figures.It remains unclear where the duo go from here, but it is understood that Walmart will continue to look to sell Asda to another buyer.Walmart chief executive Judith McKenna said: ldquoWhile wersquore disappointed by the CMArsquos final report and conclusions, our focus now is continuing to position Asda as a strong UK retailer delivering for customers. Walmart will ensure Asda has the resources it needs to achieve that.Roger Burnley, the Asda boss, said that he is ldquodisappointed in the CMArsquos decision.

title: rbs-chief-ross-mcewan-steps-down
story: Ross McEwan, who was also the banks Executive Director, said it had been"priviledge" to lead the bank, but now was the right time togohaving put most of his restructuring plan in place.Mr McEwan spent more than half a decade in the hotseat, and his tenure saw the bank cut many branches on the high street.The state-backed lender swung the axe on  branches on Scotland ndash more than one-third of its total ndash in its most recent wave of closures in late .:The most powerful woman in UK banking unveils her plans for the futureIt emphasised the continuing, dramatic reduction in branch numbers at the bank, which had more than  in .Mr McEwan has a  month notice period and will remain in his position until a successor has been appointed and an orderly handover has taken place.The effective date of his departure will be confirmed in due course.Mr McEwan said: ldquoAfter over five and a half very rewarding years, and with the bank in a much stronger financial position, it is time for me to step down as CEO."It has been a privilege to lead this great bank and to have worked with some really outstanding people in the process.:RBS executives braced for questions over pensions and pay"It is never easy to leave somewhere like RBS. However with much of the restructuring done and the bank on a strong and profitable footing, I have delivered the strategy that I set out inand now feels like the right time for me to step aside and for anew CEO to lead the bank."Ross McEwanChairman Howard Davies added: ldquoFor the past five and a half years Ross has worked tirelessly to make the bank stronger and safer and played the central role in delivering ato profitability and idend payments to shareholders."The Board and I are grateful for the huge contributionRoss has made in one of the toughest jobs in banking. His successful execution of the strategy to refocus the bank back on its core markets here in the UK and Ireland has helped to deliver one of the biggest UK corporate turnarounds in history.:RBS chief admits branch closures have been hard for customers#"RBS is nowwell positioned to succeed in the future in what is a rapidly evolving landscape for the banking sector. We will be conducting an internal and external search for his successor, which will start immediately.Mr McEwan took up the post in October  and has led the bank through testing times, having been left largely in the hands of the State after a mammoth pound billion taxpayer bailout amid the financial crisis.It was more than  per centowned by the Government at one stage, but the taxpayers stake has since reduced to .%.Mr McEwan has presided over ato profit at RBS, with the -year-old New Zealander seeing the lender report its second successive year in the black for  and announcing a pound. billion final idend, resulting in a near pound billion windfall for the taxpayer.The lender saw bottom-line profits more than double from pound million last year to pound. billion, a % increase.Full year pre-tax operating profit rose % to pound. billion. It marked the banks second year of profits following a decade-long run of stinging losses, during a period marred by crisis-era legacy and conduct charges.Shares slipped % after news of Mr McEwans departure.

title: scottish-independence-how-european-media-reacted-to-nicola-sturgeons-indyref2-update
story: The First Minister announced plans to introduce legislation that would set out rules for another vote.:Nicola Sturgeon planning Indyref before  ballotIn an address to the Scottish Parliament, Nicola Sturgeonclaimed this position was "unsustainable" and challenged her party to increase support and demand for independence.She said:"If we are to safeguard Scotlands interests, we cannot wait indefinitely."That is why I consider that a choice between Brexit and a future for Scotland as an independent European nation should be offered in the letime of this parliament."I can confirm that the Scottish government will act to ensure that the option of giving people a choice on independence later in this term of parliament is progressed."But with Brexit on the forefront of many minds, how was the announcement received in the rest of Europe France  reported: "Around six in ten Scots voted to stay in the European Union, and Sturgeon hopes that some of those who voted to stay in the United Kingdom might change their vote in another referendum in order to maintain membership of the EU."But the uncertainty surrounding Brexit, which has been put back to October  as MPs try and reach agreement over the orce deal, has also hampered plans for another independence referendum.:The key points from Nicola Sturgeons Scottish Independence update"While polls show some pro-EU voters have swung behind the independence cause, a similar amount of pro-Brexit supporters have moved in the other direction, and overall support remains close to  levels."Sturgeon hopes that dissatisfaction with Londons handling of Brexit could tip the balance."French newspaper Le Monde wrote in an analysis piece: "To convinceScots to reject independence in , one of the arguments put forward was the risk of separating, as part ofthe United Kingdom, from the European Union. A few years later, with Brexit, membership in the United Kingdom has paradoxically forced Scotland to leave the EU."French publication LEcho also highlighted Brexit as a reason for the call for independence saying: "Like Northern Ireland, the Scots voted against the Brexit in the British referendum on  June . England and Wales voted for Brexit in the majority."German publication Der Tagesspiegel wrote: "Despite the British Governments refusal to repeat the referendum on independence, Sturgeon was convinced on Wednesday that the project was likely to succeed. If the demand for independence continues to gain ground, then "no government in the United Kingdom can break the will of the people," she said."It also added analysis saying that "the First Ministers referendum demands are not necessarily based on the will of the Scottish majority. According to polls, a scant majority of Scots remain against independence." adding that a majority of Sots envisage a referendum in the next decade.Spanish newspaper El Paisbranded the announcementby the First Minister as "a calculated move" in relationto the upcoming SNP conference. The Spanish paper reported:"Brexit, as in so many other things, is the ultimate cause of awakening a new monster in the United Kingdom. Although not, in this case. This is notsomething spontaneous, but a calculated and partisan movement. Nicola Sturgeon unveiled on Wednesday herplans to push another referendum on independence in . She did it three days before the Scottish Nationalist Partyconference, to appease the nerves of the organisation.":Iain Macwhirter: Therersquos no need for the SNP to take a pounding over currency issueCatalan publication El Nacional reacted favourably to the announcement reporting ona tweet from CarlesPuigdemont: "The president in exile,Carles Puigdemont, has applaudedthe decision of the First Minister of Scotland,Nicola Sturgeon, to holda second referendum on independencebefore the end of spring"I welcome todayrsquos decision by First Minister of Scotland @NicolaSturgeon to organize a second Independence Referendum #IndyRef. The right to self-determination will be exercised with normality once again in EuropeDe Telegraaf from the Netherlands reported on the creation of The Voices for Scotland initiative which it said "hopes to get support from  to  percent of the Scots for separation. The launch comes one day after Nicola Sturgeon, Scotlands First Minister, has said that the country will prepare for a second referendum on independence before May ."Thereported Nicola Sturgeons announcement in the same story as their piece on Tory MPs asking for Theresa May to set out resignation timetable reporting: "Scotlandrsquos First MinisterNicola Sturgeonsaid she would introduce legislation allowing for a second referendum on Scottish independence by Brexit goes ahead. But she declined to set a date for a referendum and said she would establish citizensrsquo assemblies toconsider Scotlandrsquos constitutional future."

title: voices-for-scotland-civic-group-to-launch-to-help-boost-support-for-scottish-independence
story: The new civic campaign body, Voices for Scotland,will be launched this morning inEdinburghby SIC convenor Elaine C Smith, accompanied by members of the board appointed to run the new group.:Scottish independence: How European media reacted to Nicola Sturgeons indyref updateThe body, which has been launched a day after Nicola Sturgeon set out her plans for a potential second referendum,is to be headed up by long-term independence supporter Chris Hegarty with Elaine C Smith on the board alongside former MSP Dave Thompson.Ms Smith, who chairs the SIC said: ldquoThe UK is in the middle of a political crisis and wersquore launching because, important as the views of politicians are, there are many more voices in Scotland which need to be heard as we debate our future.ldquoAbout a third of those voices are definite independence supporters and about a third are definitely not. Wersquore all about opening conversations with the third of people who are in the middle, who are undecided or are doubting their previous opinions.The new body is largely funded by small donations from the public. Its board members include Greens co-leader Maggie Chapman and human rights lawyer Aamer Anwar.:Nicola Sturgeon planning Indyref before  ballotBut Pamela Nash, chief executive of Scotland in Union, said: ldquoThis is yet another anti-UK campaign group that will only be talking to a minority of people in Scotland.ldquoRegardless of how many campaigns to leave the UK are established, they will be unable to produce a positive vision for breaking up the UK because there isnrsquot one.ldquoThe majority of people in Scotland know we are stronger together and want the SNP and its allies to drop plans for a isive and unwanted second independence referendum.

title: scottish-independence-prospectus-to-be-sent-to-every-household-in-scotland
story: The move comes as Nicola Sturgeonlaunched a fresh drive for independence after announcing plans for a second referendum within the next two years Brexitgoes ahead.:Nicola Sturgeon planning Indyref before  ballot# Wersquore planning a new campaign focused on Scotlandrsquos economic potential as an independent country. Our plan is to distribute An Independent Scotland: Household Guide to every home ndash all ,, of them.Go to https:t.co JcyIwgffqM to make a donation. pic uuqeBSzjVAfter her Holyroodstatement, Ms Sturgeonrsquos husband, the SNP chief executive Peter Murrell, launched a fundraising website called yes.scot, which had previously belonged to the failed Yes Scotland campaign of .:Voices for Scotland: Civic group to launch to help boost support for Scottish independenceIt said the First Minister had given ldquonew impetus to our campaigning and appealed for cash to help the SNP win the EU election on May .It also asked for money to send all . million households an economic case for leaving the UK called An Independent Scotland: Household Guide.
